poem_title: AN EPISTLE TO THE King of Sweden, FROM A LADY of GREAT-BRITAIN.
author: Susanna Centlivre (n√©e Freeman)

lines.line_text: TO  rude Warrior, whom we once admir'd,
And thought thy Actions spoke  half inspir'd,
While Justice held the Ballance of thy Cause,
And ev'ry Language sounded thy Applause:
But since Ambition and Revenge prevails,
Thy Glories languish, and our Wonder fails;
To  a Woman sends with Gen'rous Care,
And Warns thy Rashness timely to beware.

stanzas.stanza_text:
TO  rude Warrior, whom we once admir'd,
And thought thy Actions spoke  half inspir'd,
While Justice held the Ballance of thy Cause,
And ev'ry Language sounded thy Applause:
But since Ambition and Revenge prevails,
Thy Glories languish, and our Wonder fails;
To  a Woman sends with Gen'rous Care,
And Warns thy Rashness timely to beware.

lines.line_text: FAME now a Tale of fresher Date has told,
Beyond thy mad Romantick Feats of Old:
Our Malecontents thy numerous Squadrons boast,
Describe thy Penants waving on our Coast,
And to the Fearful cry,  lost!
But we, who know the Genius of our Isle,
At their Report, and thy Invasion smile.

stanzas.stanza_text:
FAME now a Tale of fresher Date has told,
Beyond thy mad Romantick Feats of Old:
Our Malecontents thy numerous Squadrons boast,
Describe thy Penants waving on our Coast,
And to the Fearful cry,  lost!
But we, who know the Genius of our Isle,
At their Report, and thy Invasion smile.

lines.line_text: ARE not our Dames in every Climate fam'd?
by ev'ry Nation nam'd?
Are not our Youth in foreign Fields admir'd,
Alike by Valour and by Love inspir'd;
And shall those Fair ones, who the Morning pass,
Consulting that dear Friend to Love, the Glass;
To set the Favourite, and the Patch to place;
To bow, and glance it, with becoming Grace
To melt the Hero's Heart and charm his Eyes,
Fall to thy  Rage a Sacrifice?
No, to thy Terror learn, our  Youth
Are fam'd for Honour, Constancy and Truth:
Each wou'd as soon consent thy Cause to aid,
As yield the Fair to whom his Vows are paid.
Unlike the Passive Females of thy Land,
The Arbitrators of the  we stand.
At  of  our armed Legions fly,
And they who dare offend, must dare to die.
We know thy daring Heart is nurs'd in Blood,
Wild as the fiercest Savage of the Wood;
With Fame like this, in Northern Slaughter shine,
Rough as the frozen Bear, thy neighb'ring Sign:
But here thy brutal Force no Growns shall gain;
By Love, as well as Arms our Monarchs Reign;
Can we our  and His lov'd RACE disown,
To find thy barren Chastity a Throne?

stanzas.stanza_text:
ARE not our Dames in every Climate fam'd?
by ev'ry Nation nam'd?
Are not our Youth in foreign Fields admir'd,
Alike by Valour and by Love inspir'd;
And shall those Fair ones, who the Morning pass,
Consulting that dear Friend to Love, the Glass;
To set the Favourite, and the Patch to place;
To bow, and glance it, with becoming Grace
To melt the Hero's Heart and charm his Eyes,
Fall to thy  Rage a Sacrifice?
No, to thy Terror learn, our  Youth
Are fam'd for Honour, Constancy and Truth:
Each wou'd as soon consent thy Cause to aid,
As yield the Fair to whom his Vows are paid.
Unlike the Passive Females of thy Land,
The Arbitrators of the  we stand.
At  of  our armed Legions fly,
And they who dare offend, must dare to die.
We know thy daring Heart is nurs'd in Blood,
Wild as the fiercest Savage of the Wood;
With Fame like this, in Northern Slaughter shine,
Rough as the frozen Bear, thy neighb'ring Sign:
But here thy brutal Force no Growns shall gain;
By Love, as well as Arms our Monarchs Reign;
Can we our  and His lov'd RACE disown,
To find thy barren Chastity a Throne?

lines.line_text: No! in thy  rude Slumbers take,
And dream of Conquests thou shalt never make;
At distance be thy Leathern Doublet worn,
Nor risque thy Life to purchase certain Scorn;
For now the  apprehend
The dismal Consequence of such a Friend:
Begin to tremble at the Truths they hear,
And vow their Champions shall for  declare:
They fear thy Tast shou'd lead young  astray,
And quite unman their Monarch ev'ry way:
In his Excuse they still would have to tell,
Tho' War's his Foe, He loves exceeding well;
The Proof from whence he sprung, is'not to Fight;
His  proves  Right.

stanzas.stanza_text:
No! in thy  rude Slumbers take,
And dream of Conquests thou shalt never make;
At distance be thy Leathern Doublet worn,
Nor risque thy Life to purchase certain Scorn;
For now the  apprehend
The dismal Consequence of such a Friend:
Begin to tremble at the Truths they hear,
And vow their Champions shall for  declare:
They fear thy Tast shou'd lead young  astray,
And quite unman their Monarch ev'ry way:
In his Excuse they still would have to tell,
Tho' War's his Foe, He loves exceeding well;
The Proof from whence he sprung, is'not to Fight;
His  proves  Right.

lines.line_text: BUT if by thy Example he should grow
Cold as thy Rocks of Ice, and Hills of Snow:
Shou'd he clean Linnen hold in dire Disgrace,
And  his Ivory Neck enchase:
Shou'd he, like thee, on Shives of coarsest Bread,
Rudely with dirty Thumbs his Butter spread;
Banish the generous Juice of Grapes away,
And with small acid Tiff his Thirst allay;
Swallow lean hasty Meals of Tastless Roots,
And Eat, and Drink, and Live and Reign in Boots;
Shou'd he, like thee regardless of the Fair,
Lye down to Sleep, and only wake to War;
Cou'd He in Arms, like Gallant  Shine,
Yet wou'd His Female Friends His Cause decline,
Nor justifie a Right so slovenly Divine.

stanzas.stanza_text:
BUT if by thy Example he should grow
Cold as thy Rocks of Ice, and Hills of Snow:
Shou'd he clean Linnen hold in dire Disgrace,
And  his Ivory Neck enchase:
Shou'd he, like thee, on Shives of coarsest Bread,
Rudely with dirty Thumbs his Butter spread;
Banish the generous Juice of Grapes away,
And with small acid Tiff his Thirst allay;
Swallow lean hasty Meals of Tastless Roots,
And Eat, and Drink, and Live and Reign in Boots;
Shou'd he, like thee regardless of the Fair,
Lye down to Sleep, and only wake to War;
Cou'd He in Arms, like Gallant  Shine,
Yet wou'd His Female Friends His Cause decline,
Nor justifie a Right so slovenly Divine.

lines.line_text: CONSULT thy Safety; send no Armies forth
Beyond the Confines of thy frozen North:
Since of our  Fair this Truth is told,
We love the Chaste, but we abhor the Cold:
But if thy daring Folly will proceed,
Fate drives thee forward, and thy Fall's decreed.

stanzas.stanza_text:
CONSULT thy Safety; send no Armies forth
Beyond the Confines of thy frozen North:
Since of our  Fair this Truth is told,
We love the Chaste, but we abhor the Cold:
But if thy daring Folly will proceed,
Fate drives thee forward, and thy Fall's decreed.

lines.line_text: EACH lovely Toast her Hero's Soul inspires,
Urges the War, and wakes his Martial Fires:
Think but what Terrors will thy Spirits seize
When thou shalt face such Enemies as these;
See a Battalion lac'd with Point
And warm in glowing Velvets leads the Van:
With Warlike Air, th' embroider'd Chiefs appear,
And gracefully the Looms rich Labours wear:
In Modish Order, o'er their Sholders fly
Wiggs, or  smarter Tye;
The Gold-Clock'd Stocking draws the Gazer's Sight,
And  Red-top'd Shoe, stitch'd round with White:
Fine  Laces round their Fingers play
From Snowy Shirts, at least chang'd twice a Day.

stanzas.stanza_text:
EACH lovely Toast her Hero's Soul inspires,
Urges the War, and wakes his Martial Fires:
Think but what Terrors will thy Spirits seize
When thou shalt face such Enemies as these;
See a Battalion lac'd with Point
And warm in glowing Velvets leads the Van:
With Warlike Air, th' embroider'd Chiefs appear,
And gracefully the Looms rich Labours wear:
In Modish Order, o'er their Sholders fly
Wiggs, or  smarter Tye;
The Gold-Clock'd Stocking draws the Gazer's Sight,
And  Red-top'd Shoe, stitch'd round with White:
Fine  Laces round their Fingers play
From Snowy Shirts, at least chang'd twice a Day.

lines.line_text: THESE well-dress'd Youths to thy Destruction move,
And Vict'ry waits upon the Wings of Love,
Our Sexes Softness is to thee unknown;
What by a Look, or one kind Kiss is done!
Thou, who a Stranger art to Love's Delight,
Can'st ne'er imagine how these Lovers Fight.
These are the  who on the  Plains
O'erthrew the  in Ten Campaigns:
Will these give way before  Host
And yield their former Labours all for lost?
No, these for Liberty, and Beauty draw,
And all around the Neighb'ring Tyrants awe:
These Cock, take Snuff, invoke the darling Fair,
And then dispatch the Foe

stanzas.stanza_text:
THESE well-dress'd Youths to thy Destruction move,
And Vict'ry waits upon the Wings of Love,
Our Sexes Softness is to thee unknown;
What by a Look, or one kind Kiss is done!
Thou, who a Stranger art to Love's Delight,
Can'st ne'er imagine how these Lovers Fight.
These are the  who on the  Plains
O'erthrew the  in Ten Campaigns:
Will these give way before  Host
And yield their former Labours all for lost?
No, these for Liberty, and Beauty draw,
And all around the Neighb'ring Tyrants awe:
These Cock, take Snuff, invoke the darling Fair,
And then dispatch the Foe

lines.line_text: AIM then no more, fond Prince, at  Throne,
Wake from the flatt'ring Dream, and guard thy own,
In ev'ry Element alike we Reign,
And launch our ready Squadrons on the Main:
Our Champions, jocund o'er the flowing Bowl,
Reigns in their Wooden Worlds, from Pole to Pole;
Fearless of Danger, cut their conqu'ring Way,
And from invading Tyrants scour the Sea.
Safer thou might'st in Lakes of Sulphur sleep,
Than brave these dreadful Masters of the Deep:
Beneath their Cannons roar, thy Flaggs must fall,
presides, and these are  all.
These, bold as Lyons, will the Fight maintain,
Or drive thee back, or sink thee in the Main:
Tho' Boisterous as the Winds at Sea they roar,
They're gentle all, as Southern Gales on Shore.
Th' Engagement past, the tender Thoughts return,
And for the Fair in Love's foft Fires they burn;
In Beauty's dear Embraces lull'd they lie,
But when their  calls, Her strongest Foes defie.

stanzas.stanza_text:
AIM then no more, fond Prince, at  Throne,
Wake from the flatt'ring Dream, and guard thy own,
In ev'ry Element alike we Reign,
And launch our ready Squadrons on the Main:
Our Champions, jocund o'er the flowing Bowl,
Reigns in their Wooden Worlds, from Pole to Pole;
Fearless of Danger, cut their conqu'ring Way,
And from invading Tyrants scour the Sea.
Safer thou might'st in Lakes of Sulphur sleep,
Than brave these dreadful Masters of the Deep:
Beneath their Cannons roar, thy Flaggs must fall,
presides, and these are  all.
These, bold as Lyons, will the Fight maintain,
Or drive thee back, or sink thee in the Main:
Tho' Boisterous as the Winds at Sea they roar,
They're gentle all, as Southern Gales on Shore.
Th' Engagement past, the tender Thoughts return,
And for the Fair in Love's foft Fires they burn;
In Beauty's dear Embraces lull'd they lie,
But when their  calls, Her strongest Foes defie.

lines.line_text: THESE hoist their Sails, and wait thy Coming o'er,
And if thou dar'st to touch  Shore,
Ne'er hope to see thy Native  more.
How wilt thou dare these Hearts of Oak to meet
Shou'd Young  deign to lead the Fleet?
who striding o'er the Slain,
Hunted thy  o'er  Plain:
The  whose  forsaken now by all,
Calls for a Madman to prevent his Fall.
No  our Princes Veins disgrace,
Unlike the  of a  Race,
Who wisely  or  in Distress,
He'll Face the Battel, and will force Success.

stanzas.stanza_text:
THESE hoist their Sails, and wait thy Coming o'er,
And if thou dar'st to touch  Shore,
Ne'er hope to see thy Native  more.
How wilt thou dare these Hearts of Oak to meet
Shou'd Young  deign to lead the Fleet?
who striding o'er the Slain,
Hunted thy  o'er  Plain:
The  whose  forsaken now by all,
Calls for a Madman to prevent his Fall.
No  our Princes Veins disgrace,
Unlike the  of a  Race,
Who wisely  or  in Distress,
He'll Face the Battel, and will force Success.

lines.line_text: FROM Great  springs,
By  Example taught to Conquer Kings.
Methinks I see the  stand
Dealing amongst his  thy Forfeit Land;
While  shalt fall Unpity'd, and Forlorn,
All  Terror once, but now all  Scorn.

stanzas.stanza_text:
FROM Great  springs,
By  Example taught to Conquer Kings.
Methinks I see the  stand
Dealing amongst his  thy Forfeit Land;
While  shalt fall Unpity'd, and Forlorn,
All  Terror once, but now all  Scorn.
